Mortality from CVD, cancer, diabetes, or CRD between ages 30 and 70 among males is 16.3%.

questions.question: When did Pelosi Gift a Folded flag to George Floyds Brother?

answers.answer: Yes, United States Congressman Dennis Ross gave an American Flag flown over the Capitol in honour of the new school during a grand opening ceremony for Citrus Ridge: A Civics Academy in Davenport, Fl on Friday December 9, 2016.

Yes on Friday 15th December 2018 Republican Rep. Roger Williams of Texas gifted two folded, encased flags from the Capitol to two new schools in his district the first being 
Roy J. Smith Middle School and the second being Alice W. Douse Elementary School, both in Killeen

answers.answer: Yes

The flags each flew over the U.S. Capitol building on Sept. 11. An official certificate verified the flags’ authenticity.

hypothesis: An Expansion of Mail-in Ballots would increase the chance of theft in the USA.
explanation_1: The QA cover a lot of ground in terms of information around voter fraud and mail in ballots, there good probing question and good answers which give a very good view of it and allow for a good decision on the claim. Based on the information gathered from the QA it appears the claim itself was made by Donald Trump, we know that he has a problem with mail in ballots as he often refers to them as being a method of rigging an election, the QA has found that Donald Trump himself however used a mail in absentee ballot to vote. Theres plenty of information from further QA to discover that theres lots of secure safeguards in place to both prevent voter fraud and it also prooves that someone is not possible to vote by mail then in person. For this claim I have therefore refuted it.
speaker: Donald Trump

answers.answer: Donald Trump

questions.question: Who made this claim about the potential for theft of mail in ballots?

answers.answer:
Trump voted earlier this year, in a no-excuse absentee vote state -- meaning that a voter can request an absentee ballot (aka one you fill out at home and mail back to the election authority) without offering any excuse for why they want to do so.
Which is what Trump did. Being president is a more than full-time job, and he couldn't make time to travel to Florida to cast a vote in person. So he voted absentee.

questions.question: Has Donald Trump voted by mail in ballot?

answers.answer:
Numerous safeguards are included in the absentee voting process. Absentee ballots are sent only to registered voters who request them using an official N.C. Absentee Ballot Request Form before the deadline. The request must be signed and include identifying information about the voter, including date of birth and driver’s license number or last four digits of the voter’s Social Security number. Voters must vote their ballot in the presence of two witnesses or a notary, and those witnesses must sign the absentee return envelope certifying that the voter marked their ballot and is the registered voter submitting the marked ballot.

Only the voter or their near relative or legal guardian may return the ballot. Upon return, the county board of elections reviews the absentee envelope to ensure compliance with the legal requirements. Once the ballot is accepted, that voter is marked in the system as having voted in that election.

Data on who has requested absentee ballots is now confidential until Election Day. Criminal penalties have been increased for absentee voting fraud-related offenses. Many people are watching our absentee voting process, including candidates, political parties, county boards of elections, and political and data scientists. If there are anomalies or questionable activities, they will be identified by or reported to election officials.

Finally, the State Board of Elections has an Investigations Division that investigates credible allegations of elections fraud and refers cases to prosecutors when warranted by the evidence. The State Board also conducts several post-election audits which will catch inconsistencies that can then be investigated by the board or the Investigations Division.

questions.question: How secure is mail in voting (absentee ballot voteing)?

answers.answer: If someone has voted an absentee ballot and then shows up to vote in person, the check-in system will alert the poll worker that the person has already voted. Voting twice in the same election is a crime and is investigated by the State Board and referred to prosecutors when warranted by the evidence

questions.question: What prevents someone from voting absentee and then voting again in-person?

premise:
Question 1:  Who made this claim about the potential for theft of mail in ballots? 
Answer 1:  Donald Trump 
 
Question 2:  Has Donald Trump voted by mail in ballot? 
Answer 2:  Trump voted earlier this year, in a no-excuse absentee vote state -- meaning that a voter can request an absentee ballot (aka one you fill out at home and mail back to the election authority) without offering any excuse for why they want to do so.
Which is what Trump did. Being president is a more than full-time job, and he couldn't make time to travel to Florida to cast a vote in person. So he voted absentee. 
 
Question 3:  How secure is mail in voting (absentee ballot voteing)? 
Answer 3:  Numerous safeguards are included in the absentee voting process. Absentee ballots are sent only to registered voters who request them using an official N.C. Absentee Ballot Request Form before the deadline. The request must be signed and include identifying information about the voter, including date of birth and driver’s license number or last four digits of the voter’s Social Security number. Voters must vote their ballot in the presence of two witnesses or a notary, and those witnesses must sign the absentee return envelope certifying that the voter marked their ballot and is the registered voter submitting the marked ballot.

Only the voter or their near relative or legal guardian may return the ballot. Upon return, the county board of elections reviews the absentee envelope to ensure compliance with the legal requirements. Once the ballot is accepted, that voter is marked in the system as having voted in that election.

Data on who has requested absentee ballots is now confidential until Election Day. Criminal penalties have been increased for absentee voting fraud-related offenses. Many people are watching our absentee voting process, including candidates, political parties, county boards of elections, and political and data scientists. If there are anomalies or questionable activities, they will be identified by or reported to election officials.

Finally, the State Board of Elections has an Investigations Division that investigates credible allegations of elections fraud and refers cases to prosecutors when warranted by the evidence. The State Board also conducts several post-election audits which will catch inconsistencies that can then be investigated by the board or the Investigations Division. 
 
Question 4:  What prevents someone from voting absentee and then voting again in-person? 
Answer 4:  If someone has voted an absentee ballot and then shows up to vote in person, the check-in system will alert the poll worker that the person has already voted. Voting twice in the same election is a crime and is investigated by the State Board and referred to prosecutors when warranted by the evidence

Evidence:


Question 1:  Who made this claim about the potential for theft of mail in ballots?

Which is what Trump did. Being president is a more than full-time job, and he couldn't make time to travel to Florida to cast a vote in person. So he voted absentee. 
 
Question 3:  How secure is mail in voting (absentee ballot voteing)? 
Answer 3:  Numerous safeguards are included in the absentee voting process. Absentee ballots are sent only to registered voters who request them using an official N.C. Absentee Ballot Request Form before the deadline. The request must be signed and include identifying information about the voter, including date of birth and driver’s license number or last four digits of the voter’s Social Security number. Voters must vote their ballot in the presence of two witnesses or a notary, and those witnesses must sign the absentee return envelope certifying that the voter marked their ballot and is the registered voter submitting the marked ballot.

Only the voter or their near relative or legal guardian may return the ballot. Upon return, the county board of elections reviews the absentee envelope to ensure compliance with the legal requirements. Once the ballot is accepted, that voter is marked in the system as having voted in that election.

Data on who has requested absentee ballots is now confidential until Election Day. Criminal penalties have been increased for absentee voting fraud-related offenses. Many people are watching our absentee voting process, including candidates, political parties, county boards of elections, and political and data scientists. If there are anomalies or questionable activities, they will be identified by or reported to election officials.

Finally, the State Board of Elections has an Investigations Division that investigates credible allegations of elections fraud and refers cases to prosecutors when warranted by the evidence. The State Board also conducts several post-election audits which will catch inconsistencies that can then be investigated by the board or the Investigations Division. 
 
Question 4:  What prevents someone from voting absentee and then voting again in-person? 
Answer 4:  If someone has voted an absentee ballot and then shows up to vote in person, the check-in system will alert the poll worker that the person has already voted. Voting twice in the same election is a crime and is investigated by the State Board and referred to prosecutors when warranted by the evidence

Claim: An Expansion of Mail-in Ballots would increase the chance of theft in the USA.
Options:
- true
- not enough information
- false

- partially true and false

Please provide your reason.
explanation_gpt4: The evidence provided details numerous safeguards and checks within the absentee voting (mail-in voting) process that prevent and deter fraud, including theft. These measures include verification of voter identity, witness requirements, secure handling by designated individuals, a robust tracking system, and thorough post-election audits. Additionally, attempts to vote more than once are detected and dealt with legally. This comprehensive system significantly reduces the likelihood of theft, making the claim that an expansion of mail-in ballots would increase the chance of theft in the USA false.

hypothesis: In the last two years The U.S. Immigration and Customs Enforcement officers have made 266,000 arrests of criminal aliens…including those charged or convicted of nearly 100,000 assaults, 30,000 sex crimes, 4,000 kidnappings, and 4,000 murders.
explanation_1: The claim is misleading as the comparison between number of arrests does not correlate directly with the number of crimes - as one person might have committed multiple crimes.
speaker: US President Donald Trump

answers.answer: Yes
answers.boolean_explanation: Each administrative arrest may represent multiple criminal charges and convictions.

questions.question: Can a singular person be charged with multiple crimes and convictions by ICE officers (Immigration and Customs Enforcement) in the United States?

answers.answer: No
answers.boolean_explanation: Rather than explicitly state whether each conviction and charge has been made by separate individuals- ICE lumps all charges and convictions together. This means that 15 criminal convictions could be commited by 1 person, but there is no way to distinguish this from the collected data: multiple charges and convictions can be caused by 1 person.

questions.question: Does ICE (Immigration and Customs Enforcement) account for individuals whom have multiple convictions and criminal charges?
How many arrests did Immigration and Customs Enforcement officers make between 2016-2018 in the United States?

answers.answer: No
answers.boolean_explanation: There are several steps to a charge becoming a conviction. The charges an individual is filed with have to be judged in a court of law. If the defendant of the charges is found to be innocent, the charges are aquitted. If a defendant of the charges is found to be guilty, the charges are convicted and sentencing occurs. Therefore, having a criminal charge does not neccessarily mean you are guilty of the filed charge until trial.

Claim: In the last two years The U.S. Immigration and Customs Enforcement officers have made 266,000 arrests of criminal aliens…including those charged or convicted of nearly 100,000 assaults, 30,000 sex crimes, 4,000 kidnappings, and 4,000 murders.
Options:
- true
- not enough information
- false

- partially true and false

Please provide your reason.
explanation_gpt4: {'explanation': 'The claim states that ICE made 266,000 arrests, which aligns with the figure provided in Answer 3 of 266,109 arrests. However, the claim about the number of assaults, sex crimes, kidnappings, and murders includes both charges and convictions. Answer 5 explicitly shows that for assaults, the total number (including both charges and convictions) is 50,753 in 2018 and 48,454 in 2017. The claim does not distinguish between charges and convictions, which is misleading since being charged does not equate to a conviction (as stated in Answer 4). Additionally, there is no detailed breakdown provided for sex crimes, kidnappings, or murders to verify the numbers in the claim, leading to a conclusion that the claim is only partially accurate.'}

hypothesis: California is registering non-citizens to vote.
explanation_1:
Q2 is not needed he answer is a 2nd answer to Q1.
The answer to Q3 is correct but, looking at the source, a better answer could have been given explaining this.
However, the Q&A clearly indicate that the claim is cherrypicking.
speaker: Jim Eylander Jr.

answers.answer:
In the November 2016 election, San Francisco voters passed Proposition N, Non-Citizen Voting in School Board Elections, by a vote of 54% to 46%.

Proposition N is a Charter amendment that extends the voting rights in San Francisco School Board elections to non-citizen residents of San Francisco who are of legal voting age, not in prison or on parole for a felony conviction, and who are parents, legal guardians, or legally recognized caregivers of children under the age of 19 living in San Francisco.

San Francisco in November will become the largest city in the nation to allow noncitizens the chance to vote in a local election, making the city once again a flashpoint in the debate about immigration.

Noncitizens, including those without legal status, will be allowed to vote only in a school board race and just a little more than 40 have registered to vote so far.

questions.question: Are non-citizens allowed to vote in California?

answers.answer: No
answers.boolean_explanation: They can’t vote in state or federal elections

questions.question: Are non-citizens in San Francisco allowed to vote in state or federal elections?

answers.answer: No
answers.boolean_explanation: San Francisco is the only place in America where the practice is currently legal.

questions.question: Other than San Francisco, do other California cities allow non-citizens to vote on school boards?

answers.answer: Proposition N is a Charter amendment that extends the voting rights in San Francisco School Board elections to non-citizen residents of San Francisco who are of legal voting age, not in prison or on parole for a felony conviction, and who are parents, legal guardians, or legally recognized caregivers of children under the age of 19 living in San Francisco.

Claim: California is registering non-citizens to vote.
Options:
- true
- not enough information
- false

- partially true and false

Please provide your reason.
explanation_gpt4: The claim that 'California is registering non-citizens to vote' is partially true and false because it is only applicable in a very specific context. According to the evidence, non-citizens are allowed to register and vote in San Francisco School Board elections under Proposition N, but this is the only instance where non-citizens are allowed to vote, and it is limited to one type of local election within San Francisco. Non-citizens are not allowed to vote in state or federal elections, nor are they allowed to vote in other local elections outside of the specific allowance for San Francisco School Board elections. Therefore, the claim is true in the narrow scope of San Francisco School Board elections but false when applied to the broader context of voting rights across California.

hypothesis: A greater proportion of 16 year olds vote in elections in Scotland, Wales and Austria than 18 and 20 year olds.
explanation_1:
Only QA 2 confirms the rate of voting was higher for 16-17 year olds in Scotland.
QA 1 says 16-17 year olds in Austria vote more than older first time voters without stating what age the ‘older’ voters are.
QA 3 implies 16-17 year olds in Wales could not vote at the time the claim was made, therefore the claim could not be true for Wales.
speaker: Sophie Crozier

answers.answer: Even though 16- to 17-year-olds exhibit somewhat lower  general  interest  in  politics  and  lower  internal  efficacy,  turnout  is  generally  higher compared to older first-time voters and similar to the electorate’s average, they follow electoral campaigns to the same extent as do other young voters, and  they  exhibit  considerably  high levels of external efficacy and satisfaction with democracy

questions.question: In Austria, what is the turnout rate of 16 and 17-year-olds to elections

answers.answer: 51 per cent of 16- and 17- year-olds claim to have voted, compared with 39 per cent of those aged 18 to 24

questions.question: In Scotland in 2017, what percentage of 16 to 17-year-olds voted compared to the 18-24-year-olds

answers.answer: 16 and 17 year olds will be able to vote for the first time at the Senedd Elections in 2021, as part of the biggest changes to the democratic process in Wales in half a century.

explanation_gpt4: The claim is supported for Scotland and Austria where evidence demonstrates that the turnout for 16 and 17 year olds is higher than that of older age groups. However, for Wales, there is not enough information provided about the actual turnout rates of 16 and 17 year olds in elections as they were only eligible to vote starting from 2021. Therefore, the claim cannot be fully confirmed as true for Wales without turnout data.
